Comment: The US government has not able to fully finance their spending with existing tax revenue, so they must borrow money. The way they do this is by issuing bonds. Investors give the US money to spend in return for interest payments.  For example, let’s say US Bonds pay out a total amount ($50) and start at $1000. That’s a 5% return on investment. The US government has to spend 5 cents extra of future income for every dollar raised now.  Japan holds a ton of these US bonds. If they decide to dump them and sell it at say $800, investors will buy these instead of bonds sold by the US government directly. Because the bonds are tradeable on the open market, anybody can own it and get the $50 interest payments from the USA.  In order for the USA to continue borrowing money to spend on their budget deficit, they must start offering the bonds at 50/800 = 6.25% yield. Otherwise investors just buy the US bonds from Japan which cost $800 and offer the same $50 interest. Investors will only accept an equal or better price from the US government.  So in this example the US government has to spend extra 6.25 cents of future income per dollar raised now. This makes it harder to pay back the loans, harder to generate a net positive benefit on the loans, etc.  The other option for the US government to get more money to spend is “quantitative easing” ie print more money. And that is going to devalue the US dollar, cause inflation and tank the US Dollar’s position as the world reserve currency. No country wants to hold US dollars which are getting more worthless every year.
